reporting-org.narrative: Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland

title.narrative: Quality standards for enhanced market access for small-holder farmers in Tanzania (SEMA)

description.narrative: Agriculture incl. horticulture forms an essential part of the national economy in Tanzania. Over two thirds of the work force are employed by the sector and about 60% of them are involved in crop production. Tanzania has good possibilities to increase hort iculture production and the sector is highly prioritized in government development strategies; particularly export growth is expected. The main obstacle is lack of systematic quality assurance practices and certified quality system that are mandatory for e xport. Global G.A.P. has become an industry standard and is requested in export markets. Currently Tanzania has only 14 certificate holders which is highly insufficient to meet the export targets. The domestic retail sector is emerging and consumer awarene ss awakening; safer food is strongly requested. Local G.A.P. assessment addresses domestic market demands and paves the way to Global G.A.P. certification for small holders.The project purpose is to improve small holder farmers' quality assurance skills to meet the demands of domestic and export markets thus improving their livelihoods. The project results will be achieved through:1) Improved organizational capacity of TAHA in quality assurance and social accountability2) Improved quality assurance and soci al accountability practices of member farmers3) Improved social responsibility and contractual position of small-holder farmers in the value chain + national level awareness increased on project model The project will be implemented in four regions in Tan zania: Arusha Kilimanjaro Njombe and Zanzibar. The direct beneficiaries include: 15 TAHA agronomists trained on Global G.A.P standards up to 5000 small holder farmers with improved quality assurance skills and up to 1000 farmers connected to exporters for international markets. The final beneficiaries will amount up to 25000 people.The project activities will be implemented by Tanzania Horticultural Association with FFD technical advisory in project management. Puutarhaliitto the Central Organization for Fi nnish Horticulture will act as a peer-to-peer twinning partner providing technical expertise on quality assurance systems implementation.

Agriculture incl. horticulture forms an essential part of the national economy in Tanzania. Over two thirds of the work force are employed by the sector and about 60% of them are involved in crop production. Tanzania has good possibilities to increase hort iculture production and the sector is highly prioritized in government development strategies; particularly export growth is expected. The main obstacle is lack of systematic quality assurance practices and certified quality system that are mandatory for e xport. Global G.A.P. has become an industry standard and is requested in export markets. Currently Tanzania has only 14 certificate holders which is highly insufficient to meet the export targets. The domestic retail sector is emerging and consumer awarene ss awakening; safer food is strongly requested. Local G.A.P. assessment addresses domestic market demands and paves the way to Global G.A.P. certification for small holders.The project purpose is to improve small holder farmers' quality assurance skills to meet the demands of domestic and export markets thus improving their livelihoods. The project results will be achieved through:1) Improved organizational capacity of TAHA in quality assurance and social accountability2) Improved quality assurance and soci al accountability practices of member farmers3) Improved social responsibility and contractual position of small-holder farmers in the value chain + national level awareness increased on project model The project will be implemented in four regions in Tan zania: Arusha Kilimanjaro Njombe and Zanzibar. The direct beneficiaries include: 15 TAHA agronomists trained on Global G.A.P standards up to 5000 small holder farmers with improved quality assurance skills and up to 1000 farmers connected to exporters for international markets. The final beneficiaries will amount up to 25000 people.The project activities will be implemented by Tanzania Horticultural Association with FFD technical advisory in project management. Puutarhaliitto the Central Organization for Fi nnish Horticulture will act as a peer-to-peer twinning partner providing technical expertise on quality assurance systems implementation.

activity-date.narrative: Actual start date of the activity

tag.narrative: Generating jobs, livelihood opportunities and well-being in a developing country is the main prio rity area in this activity
Improving food security, access to water and sustainability is the secondary priority area in t his activity
Strengthening of the rights and status of women and girls is a secondary priority area in this activity
